review.title: A Survey of Credit Card Fraud Detection Techniques: Data and Technique Oriented Perspective
review.abstract: Credit card plays a very important rule in today's economy. It becomes an unavoidable part of household, business and global activities. Although using credit cards provides enormous benefits when used carefully and responsibly,significant credit and financial damages may be caused by fraudulent activities. Many techniques have been proposed to confront the growth in credit card fraud. However, all of these techniques have the same goal of avoiding the credit card fraud; each one has its own drawbacks, advantages and characteristics. In this paper, after investigating difficulties of credit card fraud detection, we seek to review the state of the art in credit card fraud detection techniques, data sets and evaluation criteria.The advantages and disadvantages of fraud detection methods are enumerated and compared.Furthermore, a classification of mentioned techniques into two main fraud detection approaches, namely, misuses (supervised) and anomaly detection (unsupervised) is presented. Again, a classification of techniques is proposed based on capability to process the numerical and categorical data sets. Different data sets used in literature are then described and grouped into real and synthesized data and the effective and common attributes are extracted for further usage.Moreover, evaluation employed criterions in literature are collected and discussed.Consequently, open issues for credit card fraud detection are explained as guidelines for new researchers.

sections.text: Credit cards play a very important role in today's economy, becoming an unavoidable part of household, business and global activities. Although the use of credit cards offers enormous benefits when used carefully and responsibly, significant credit and financial damage can be caused by fraudulent activity. Many techniques have been proposed to counteract the growing credit card fraud. However, all these techniques have the same aim of avoiding credit card fraud; each has its own disadvantages, advantages and characteristics. In this paper, the difficulties in detecting credit card fraud are enumerated and compared. In addition, we try to review the state of the art in detecting credit card fraud, data sets and rating criteria. The advantages and disadvantages of fraud detection methods are enumerated and compared.A classification of the techniques mentioned into two main approaches to detecting fraud, namely misuse (monitored) and anomaly (not monitored), is proposed as a technical solution.

sections.heading: 2. Credit card fraud
sections.text: The illegal use of credit cards or their information without the knowledge of the cardholder is finally referred to as credit card fraud. Various tricks of credit card fraud belong mainly to two groups of application and conduct fraud [3]. Application fraud occurs when fraudsters use new cards from banks or issuing companies that use false or other information. Multiple applications can be submitted by one user with a set of user data (so-called duplication fraud) or by another user with identical details (so-called identity fraud). Behavioral fraud, on the other hand, has four main types: stolen / lost card, postal theft, counterfeit card and "non-existent cardholder." Stolen / lost card fraud occurs when fraudsters steal credit card or gain access to a lost card. Post theft occurs when the fraudster receives a credit card in e-mail or personal information from the bank before reaching the actual cardholder [3]. In both countries, credit card cardholders are "without the knowledge of and non-present cardholder."

sections.heading: 3. Difficulties of Credit Card Fraud Detection
sections.text: Unbalanced data: The data to detect credit card fraud is imbalanced in nature, which means that very small percentages of all credit card transactions are fraudulent. Misclassification of a normal transaction as fraud is not as harmful as detection of a fraud transaction as normal, because in the first case the error in classification is identified in further investigations. Overlapping data: Many transactions can be considered fraudulent when in fact they are normal (false positive) and vice versa a a fraudulent transaction can appear legitimate (false negative). The low rate of false positive and false negative transactions in Ukraine is a key challenge for fraud detection systems [4, 5 and 6].

sections.heading: 4. Credit Card Fraud Detection Techniques
sections.text: Credit card fraudsters are classified into two general categories: fraud analysis (abuse detection) and user behavior analysis (anomaly detection).The first group of techniques deals with supervised classification tasks at the transaction level. In these methods, transactions are referred to as fraudulent or normal fraud methods. This data set is then used to create classification models that predict the state (normal or fraud) of new records. There are numerous creation methods for a typical two-tier classification, such as rule initiation [2] and neural networks [3].This approach proves reliable for most fraud attempts observed locally.

sections.heading: 4.1 Artificial Neural Network
sections.text: An artificial neural network (ANN) is a set of interconnected nodes designed to mimic the functioning of the human brain [9]. Each node has a weighted connection to several other nodes in adjacent layers. Individual nodes absorb the inputs received from connected nodes and use the weight along with a simple function to calculate output values. Neural networks come in many shapes and architectures. The architecture of the neural network, including the number of hidden layers, the number of nodes within a particular hidden layer and their connectivity, is usually specified by the user based on the complexity of the problem. ANNs can be configured using monitored, unattended or hybrid learning methods.

[26] proposed a hybrid supervised (SICLN) and unsupervised (ICLN) learning network for detecting credit card fraud. They improved the reward rule of the SICLN model to ICLN to update weights both after reward and after punishment. This improvement was shown in terms of increasing stability and shortening training time. In addition, the number of final clusters of ICLN is independent of the number of initial network neurons. As a result, the inoperable neurons can be omitted from the clusters by applying the punitive rules.The results showed that both the ICLN and the SICLN are extremely powerful, but the SICLN exceeds known uncontrolled cluster algorithms.

sections.heading: 4.2 Artificial Immune System (AIS)
sections.text: The natural immune system is a highly complex system consisting of a complex network of specialized tissues, organs, cells and chemical molecules, which are interconnected and act in a highly coordinated and specific manner when they recognize, remember and eliminate pathogenic foreign cells. Any element that could be recognized by the immune system is called an antigen. Immune system detectors are the antibodies that are capable of recognizing harmful and risky antigens [27]. The immune system consists of the two main responses of the immune system and the acquired immune response. The body's first response to defense is the outer, unbroken skin and the "mucous membranes" that line internal channels, such as the respiratory and digestive tracts. If the harmful cells could pass through innate immune defense, the acquired immune response is replaced by the acquired defense.

In contrast, the states of an HMM are hidden, but state-dependent outputs are visible. In the detection of credit card fraud, an HMM is trained to model normal behavior in user profiles [52]. sections.heading: 4.6 Bayesian Network
sections.text: A Bayesian network is a graphical model that represents conditional dependencies between random variables, and the underlying graphical model is in the form of a directed acyclic graph. bayesian networks are useful for finding unknown probabilities in the presence of uncertainty [66]. Bayesian networks can play an important and effective role in modelling situations where some basic information is already known but incoming data is uncertain or partially unavailable [67], [68], [69]. The objective of applying the Bayes rules is often to predict the class sign associated with a particular vector of characteristics or attributes [70]. Bayesian networks have been successfully applied to various areas of interest, e.g. preventing prevention [71] in business, pattern recognition in vision [72], generating diagnoses in medicine [73] and detecting network fraud [74] as well as predicting this error in networks [74].

metadata.abstractText: Credit card plays a very important rule in today's economy. It becomes an unavoidable part of household, business and global activities. Although using credit cards provides enormous benefits when used carefully and responsibly,significant credit and financial damagesmay be causedby fraudulent activities. Many techniques have been proposed to confront thegrowthin credit card fraud. However, all of these techniques have the same goal of avoiding the credit card fraud; each one has its own drawbacks, advantages and characteristics. In this paper, after investigating difficultiesof credit card fraud detection, we seek to review the state of the art in credit card fraud detection techniques, datasets and evaluation criteria.The advantages and disadvantages of fraud detection methods are enumerated and compared.Furthermore, a classification of mentioned techniques into two main fraud detection approaches, namely, misuses (supervised) and anomaly detection (unsupervised) is presented. Again, a classification of techniques is proposed based on capability to process the numerical and categorical datasets. Different datasets used in literatureare then described and grouped into real and synthesized data and the effective and common attributesare extracted for further usage.Moreover, evaluation employed criterions in literature are collected and discussed.Consequently, open issues for credit card fraud detection are explained as guidelinesfor
